Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: The Efficacy of Support Structures for Legal Mobilization

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
Sociolegal scholarship has shown how law schools and training programs can serve as support structures that provide critical intellectual, social, and material resources for movements seeking to influence the law. While this scholarship establishes that these institutions are a necessary precondition for change, it leaves open an important question. Namely, are there types of support structures that are more or less effective at producing and facilitating the transfer of these valuable resources to and within movements? Contemporary legal movements provide a unique opportunity to address this question, as their patrons have, since the late-1990s, invested in support institutions representative of three different types - Leveraging, Supplemental, and Parallel Alternative Structures.

This study uses this variation to help forward two models for understanding and assessing the efficacy of different support structure strategies. It does this by collecting and aggregating institutional data from three law schools and one legal training program at the heart of these contemporary legal movements. PIs will supplement these data with evidence gathered from personal interviews, participant observation, and an original survey. PIs will analyze these data both qualitatively and quantitatively, with the primary methods involving interpretive data analysis and network mapping. This project will provide important insights for scholars and practitioners and will have at least two significant impacts. First, through the development of new models for understanding movements, this project will make a theoretical contribution to the scholarly literature on support structures, legal mobilization, and social movements. Secondly, policy activists who have learned that a support structure is necessary for legal change have little guidance from the literature as to what kinds of support structures will best facilitate the transfer of resources between their movement and policy demanders. This project will help inform this important policy and scholarly conversation.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This study’s broad aim was to better theorize and understand the varied means and relative effectiveness of strategies social movements use to influence law and policy. Considering this goal, the project’s case study primarily consisted of newly created law schools and training programs that stand to function as supporting institutions for emergent legal movements.

Sociolegal scholarship has shown how law schools and training programs can provide critical resources (e.g. lawyers, networks, new ideas, legitimacy, etc.) for movements seeking to influence the law. While this scholarship establishes that these institutions are a necessary precondition for change, it leaves open an important question. Namely, are there types of support structures that are more or less effective at producing and facilitating the transfer of these valuable resources within and beyond movements?

The project outcomes are as follows. First, we have provided two new theoretical models for (a) understanding how movements can develop support structures and (b) for visualizing what support structures are intended to do and what types of variables enable or inhibit their functioning. These models are intended to help scholars and students envision the complex ways that movements attempt to produce legal change, and thus to help spur future research by others.

In terms of directly addressing if there are types of support structures that are more or less effective, we provide a contingent assessment rather than a simplistic direct answer. In brief, we have argued that the first set of factors influencing the overall value for a movement are related to cost and the degree of control that one seeks to exercise over an institution. Creating wholly new institutions costs more, comes with greater risks, and one needs to be able to accept that such institutions will initially lack the reputation and access to networks that existing institutions can possess. While noted, creating wholly new institutions does allow for more control in their design and functioning which can provide its own forms of value for a movement. Pursuing existing institutions reduces these costs and allows one to benefit from preexisting investments in and gains made by an institution, but it reduces the amount of control one has over their own investment.

Another product of the study regarding effectiveness is the need to consider how complex the process of legal change is. For example, the legal world is governed by its own formal and informal rules, and the means to influence are not equally open to everyone. As a result, the study seeks to give an idea of the range of contingencies that matter for understanding how access is achieved, and the means to influence are regulated and either available or restricted.

Relatedly, the project draws attention to the need to consider support structure institutions as not just producers of goods and resources, but also as consumers of such materials. What’s more, as with most markets, the resources needed to be consumed are scarce and of variable quality. Thus, the types of support structures a movement should or should not pursue depends in part on the market for these resources.

Furthermore, assessments of value and effectiveness need to be considered in light of what the given movement, or the given institution, seeks to achieve. Just as the legal arena is complex, the aims sought by movements within it can be complicated. Yes, movements seek to win cases, and thus they want supporting institutions that will help them achieve this end. This, however, is not all that they can hope for. Instead, the study draws attention to the fact that support structures offer various products that can provide value for movements beyond just winning cases.

As a final--and ongoing--project outcome, these findings have been presented in multiple academic talks, conference papers, published scholarly articles, a university press book, and now they are starting to be presented in popular media.
